bibl.idno: Papers of Jefferson Randolph Kean [manuscript] / Jefferson Randolph Kean, 1860-1950. MSS 628. The Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia, Charlottesville, Va.

bibl.title: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Jefferson Randolph Kean, October 3, 1942

div1.p: Kellogg tells Kean of a visit with Hench in Colorado Springs, Colorado, and relates news of family and acquaintances. [Courtesy of The Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia Library]

div1.head: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Jefferson Randolph Kean, October 3, 1942
div1.opener:
GEORGE A. KELLOGG
257 CORNELISON AVENUE
JERSEY CITY, N.J.
Hotel Broadmoor
Colorado Springs, Col.
Oct. 3. '42
Dear General Kean,
div1.p:
Your recent note was
forwarded to me here. Ive had
lunch with Col. Hench and my
brother and I are having dinner
with Phil and his wife tonight.
I've watched him work in his
office at the Station Hospital and
can understand why he gets so
many things done. If he hadn't been
a physician he would have been
a fine business executive and
is one anyway.

After not seeing each other for
4½ years my brother and I are
having a fine visit. He is with
General Hospital #50 from Seattle
headed by Col. Bourbon of the
regular army and Col. H.T. Buckner
of Seattle. Buckner was with
this same unit #50 during
the last war when it was
headed by Col. Eagelson, also
of Seattle. You may have known
him.

My brother Howard is as
you know Lt. Col. in charge of
Surgery - and is drill master
as well. The boys complain
about the hikes but he's getting
them toughened up.

Next time I see you I'll
have a lot to tell you and
Mrs Kean.
div1.closer:
With kindest regards George Kellogg Had lunch with Col. Edgar Hume just before I left N. Y. C.
He says that you are the most distinguished living member of the Medical Corp.
